title: 105_s1044
content: The Act may be cited as the "Criminal Copyright Improvement Act of 1997" and addresses criminal infringement of copyrights. The "Criminal Copyright Improvement Act of 1997" amends the definition of financial gain in copyright law to include receiving anything of value, including other copyrighted works. It also specifies criminal infringement as reproducing or distributing 10 or more copies of copyrighted works with a total retail value of $5,000 or more for commercial advantage or private financial gain. The "Criminal Copyright Improvement Act of 1997" expands criminal infringement to include reproducing or distributing copyrighted works with a retail value of $5,000 or more. It also amends related sections in title 17 and title 18 of the United States Code. The "Criminal Copyright Improvement Act of 1997" increases penalties for reproducing or distributing copyrighted works with a retail value of $5,000 or more. Offenders can face up to 3 years in prison or fines as specified in the title. The Criminal Copyright Improvement Act of 1997 allows victims of copyright offenses to submit victim impact statements detailing the injury and loss suffered, including economic impact.
